text: Are there Moral Facts ?
label: root expl amod nsubj punct

text: So far , we have covered how evolutionary ethics relates to the question what we ought to do and why we are moral in the first place .
label: advmod advmod punct nsubj aux root obj amod nsubj advcl case det obl obj nsubj acl mark xcomp cc advmod nsubj cop conj case det amod obl punct

text: A related set of questions about ethics are metaethical questions , which concern the meaning of moral terms , our ways of gaining knowledge of moral facts , and the nature of the moral facts .
label: det amod nsubj case nmod case nmod cop amod root punct nsubj acl det obj case amod nmod punct nmod conj mark acl obj case amod nmod punct cc det conj case det amod nmod punct

text: In other words , apart from thinking about how we ought to live , and where our moral sense comes from , we can also ask what it means to affirm a particular answer to that question , how we could come to know the answer , and whether the answer would be a matter of fact or more like an opinion .
label: case amod obl punct advmod mark advcl case obl nsubj advcl mark xcomp punct cc conj nmod amod nsubj advcl obl punct nsubj aux advmod root obj expl acl mark csubj det amod obj case det nmod punct conj nsubj aux advcl mark xcomp det obj punct cc mark det nsubj aux cop det conj case nmod cc advmod case det conj punct

text: Many books and articles in moral philosophy start with the observation that moral judgments seem to be objectively true and the assumption that this is how non-philosophers also think about morality .
label: amod nsubj cc conj case amod nmod root case det obl mark amod nsubj acl mark cop advmod xcomp cc det conj mark nsubj cop acl nsubj advmod advcl case obl punct

text: For example , Michael Smith writes :
label: case obl punct nsubj flat root punct

text: We seem to think moral questions have correct answers ; that the correct answers are made correct by objective moral facts ; that moral facts are wholly determined by circumstances ; and that , by engaging in moral conversation and argument , we can discover what these objective facts are .
label: nsubj root mark xcomp amod nsubj ccomp amod obj punct mark det amod nsubj aux conj xcomp case amod amod obl punct mark amod nsubj aux advmod conj case obl punct cc mark punct mark advcl case amod obl cc conj punct nsubj aux conj obj det amod nsubj acl punct
punct root nmod punct dep punct

text: But as we have seen above , evolutionary theory explains why we would think that moral judgments are objective .
label: cc mark nsubj aux advcl advmod punct amod nsubj root obj nsubj aux advcl mark amod nsubj cop ccomp punct

text: The philosopher Michael Ruse takes this to show that the apparent objectivity of morality is something like an “ illusion ” foisted on us by our genes ( Ruse [ 1986 ] 1998 , 253 ) .
label: det nsubj appos flat root obj mark xcomp mark det amod nsubj case nmod cop ccomp case det punct nmod punct acl case obl case nmod obl punct dep punct nmod punct nmod punct dep punct punct

text: Of course , even if Ruse is correct , this does not show that moral judgments are not objective , but it can make us think whether the objectivity of morality really has to be explained , as many philosophers assume .
label: advmod fixed punct advmod mark nsubj cop advcl punct nsubj aux advmod root mark amod nsubj cop advmod ccomp punct cc nsubj aux conj obj xcomp mark det nsubj case nmod advmod ccomp mark aux xcomp punct mark amod nsubj advcl punct

text: Ruse has also argued that an evolutionary account of morality suggests that there are no moral facts in the first place .
label: nsubj aux advmod root mark det amod nsubj case nmod ccomp mark expl ccomp det amod nsubj case det amod obl punct

text: Anything we want to explain about morality can be explained without mentioning moral facts , or so Ruse argues .
label: nsubj nsubj acl mark xcomp case nmod aux aux root mark advcl amod obj punct cc advmod nsubj conj punct

text: If moral facts are explanatorily redundant , indeed , moral realists ( those who believe there are mind - independent , objective facts about morality , as discussed in Chapter 1 ) need to say why we should still suppose that moral facts do exist .
label: mark amod nsubj cop advmod advcl punct advmod punct amod nsubj punct appos nsubj acl expl ccomp compound punct amod punct amod nsubj case nmod punct mark acl case obl nummod punct root mark xcomp obj nsubj aux advmod advcl mark amod nsubj aux ccomp punct

text: Interestingly , Ruse ’s methodological naturalism leads him to embrace a view that goes against the metaphysical naturalist position that moral facts exist .
label: advmod punct nmod case amod nsubj root obj mark xcomp det obj nsubj acl case det amod compound obl mark amod nsubj acl punct

text: Relatedly , Sharon Street , for example , argues that evolutionary explanations of morality show that moral realism is probably false .
label: advmod punct nsubj flat punct case obl punct root mark amod nsubj case nmod ccomp mark amod nsubj cop advmod ccomp punct

text: The kind of moral realism that Street has in mind is the view that moral properties exist as objective features of the world ( to wit , whether stealing is wrong is independent of whether anyone thinks or feels that stealing is wrong ) .
label: det nsubj case amod nmod obj nsubj acl case obl cop det root mark amod nsubj acl case amod obl case det nmod punct mark advcl punct mark csubj cop csubj cop parataxis mark mark nsubj advcl cc conj mark csubj cop ccomp punct punct

text: Street starts with the premise that our moral judgments are influenced by evolutionary forces .
label: nsubj root case det obl mark nmod amod nsubj aux acl case amod obl punct

text: This fact , Street claims , gives rise to a dilemma for moral realists concerning the relation of the evolutionary forces that influenced our moral judgments and the moral facts claimed to exist by moral realists .
label: det nsubj punct nsubj parataxis punct root obj case det obl case amod nmod acl det obj case det amod nmod nsubj acl nmod amod obj cc det amod conj acl mark xcomp case amod obl punct

text: If there is no relation between the evolutionary forces and the moral facts , then it would be an astonishing coincidence if many of our moral judgments were true .
label: mark expl advcl det nsubj case det amod nmod cc det amod conj punct advmod nsubj aux cop det amod root mark nsubj case nmod amod obl cop advcl punct

text: In light of the coincidence , we have no reason to assume that our moral judgments are true — an unpalatable conclusion for realists .
label: case obl case det nmod punct nsubj root det obj mark acl mark nmod amod nsubj cop ccomp punct det amod appos case nmod punct

text: Claiming that there is a relation , however , is empirically dubious , according to Street .
label: csubj mark expl ccomp det nsubj punct advmod punct cop advmod root punct case fixed obl punct

text: Mirroring Ruse ’s claim , moral facts could be purged from what we assume to exist because they do not perform an important explanatory function .
label: advcl nmod case obj punct amod nsubj aux aux root case obl nsubj acl mark xcomp mark nsubj aux advmod advcl det amod amod obj punct

text: So , we should reject moral realism .
label: advmod punct nsubj aux root amod obj punct

text: Street ’s argument illustrates how evolutionary theory can be used to make a case about which metaethical theories we should adopt .
label: nmod case nsubj root obj amod nsubj aux aux advcl mark advcl det obj mark det amod obj nsubj aux acl punct

text: Both Ruse ’s and Street ’s arguments rely on the idea that we should only accept that something exists if it plays an indispensable explanatory role and there are means to resist these arguments . [ 12 ]
label: cc nmod case cc conj case nsubj root case det obl mark nsubj aux advmod acl mark nsubj ccomp mark nsubj advcl det amod amod obj cc expl conj nsubj mark acl det obj punct punct dep punct

text: Both arguments , as presented here , rely on the correctness of the evolutionary explanation of morality they convey .
label: det nsubj punct mark acl advmod punct root case det obl case det amod nmod case nmod nsubj acl punct

text: In the next section , we turn to the relevance of evolutionary ethics for moral epistemology .
label: case det amod obl punct nsubj root case det obl case amod nmod case amod nmod punct

text: E.g. Enoch ( 2010 )
label: advmod root punct nmod punct

text: Can We have Justified Moral Beliefs ?
label: aux nsubj root amod amod obj punct

text: The evolutionary argument by Sharon Street can also be interpreted as an argument about moral justification and moral knowledge .
label: det amod nsubj case compound nmod aux advmod aux root case det obl case amod nmod cc amod conj punct

text: Suppose that moral realists assume that there is no relation between our moral judgments and the moral facts .
label: root mark amod nsubj ccomp mark expl ccomp det nsubj case nmod amod nmod cc det amod conj punct

text: It would seem like an incredible coincidence if the realists were right that our moral judgments are nonetheless true .
label: nsubj aux root case det amod obl mark det nsubj cop advcl mark nmod amod nsubj cop advmod advcl punct

text: There are just too many possible moral truths and too many ways in which evolution could have “ pushed ” our moral beliefs .
label: expl root advmod advmod amod amod amod nsubj cc advmod amod conj case obl nsubj aux aux punct acl punct nmod amod obj punct

text: Street claims that such a coincidence would be too much to believe .
label: nsubj root mark det det nsubj aux cop advmod ccomp mark xcomp punct

text: But what is the problem , exactly , with having beliefs that are only coincidentally true ?
label: cc nsubj cop det root punct advmod punct mark acl obj nsubj cop advmod advmod acl punct

text: Depending on how we understand “ coincidence , ” my belief that there is a bird outside my window is coincidentally true because had I looked a little later , the bird would have flown away already .
label: case fixed obl nsubj advcl punct obj punct punct nmod nsubj mark expl acl det nsubj case nmod nmod cop advmod root mark aux nsubj advcl det obl advmod punct det nsubj aux aux advcl advmod advmod punct

text: Accidentally true beliefs do not seem problematic in every case .
label: advmod amod nsubj aux advmod root xcomp case det obl punct

text: The question for proponents of Street ’s argument is to show why the evolutionary influence on human moral beliefs makes for a particularly problematic case of coincidence .
label: det nsubj case nmod case nmod case nmod cop mark root obj det amod nsubj case amod amod nmod advcl case det advmod amod obl case nmod punct

text: The philosopher Richard Joyce argues that the problem has to do with the sensitivity of our moral beliefs to the moral facts ( Joyce 2006 ) .
label: det nsubj appos flat root mark det nsubj ccomp mark xcomp case det obl case nmod amod nmod case det amod nmod punct dep nmod punct punct

text: Given that our moral beliefs are influenced by evolutionary forces , and not by the moral facts , our moral beliefs would be the same even if the moral facts would change .
label: advcl mark nmod amod nsubj aux ccomp case amod obl punct cc advmod case det amod conj punct nmod amod nsubj aux cop det root advmod mark det amod nsubj aux advcl punct

text: But because we should not hold on to such insensitive beliefs , evolutionary explanations of morality show that our moral beliefs are unjustified ( because they are not sensitive ) .
label: cc mark nsubj aux advmod advcl compound case amod amod obl punct amod nsubj case nmod root mark nmod amod nsubj cop ccomp punct mark nsubj cop advmod advcl punct punct

text: It is not clear , however , whether and why evolutionary explanations of morality reveal something about our moral beliefs that is particularly troubling from an epistemological perspective .
label: nsubj cop advmod root punct advmod punct mark cc conj amod nsubj case nmod ccomp obj case nmod amod nmod nsubj cop advmod acl case det amod obl punct

text: The impact of evolutionary ethics on epistemological questions depends on these deeper questions about epistemology . [ 13 ]
label: det nsubj case amod nmod case amod nmod root case det amod obl case nmod punct punct dep punct

text: Evolutionary explanations of morality , however , provide us with a useful starting point for thinking about these questions .
label: amod nsubj case nmod punct advmod punct root obj case det amod amod obl mark acl case det obl punct

text: See Klenk ( 2019 ) .
label: root obj punct nmod punct punct

text: CONCLUSION
label: root

text: Evolutionary ethics has helped us to get a much clearer sense of where the human moral sense is coming from .
label: amod nsubj aux root obj mark xcomp det advmod amod obj mark obl det amod amod nsubj aux acl case punct

text: While this is a far cry from revealing to us what we ought to do , the research program seems full of promise nonetheless .
label: mark nsubj cop det amod advcl mark acl case obl obj nsubj acl mark xcomp punct det compound nsubj root xcomp case obl advmod punct

text: Once we get into the details , we can see that it also raises deep theoretical questions about evolutionary explanations , the relation of descriptive and normative claims , the epistemology of justification and truth , and the general viability of naturalism in ethics .
label: mark nsubj advcl case det obl punct nsubj aux root mark nsubj advmod ccomp amod amod obj case amod nmod punct det conj case amod cc conj nmod punct det conj case nmod cc conj punct cc det amod conj case nmod case nmod punct

text: Much left to wonder , then , but with some ideas about where to get our answers .
label: nsubj root mark xcomp punct advmod punct cc case det conj case obl mark acl nmod obj punct

text: 2.2 The Motivated Learner
label: dep det amod root

text: Questions to consider :
label: root mark acl punct

text: How do different types of motivation affect my learning ?
label: advmod aux amod nsubj case nmod root nmod obj punct

text: What is resilience and grit ?
label: root cop nsubj cc conj punct

text: How can I apply the Uses and Gratification Theory to make decisions about my learning ?
label: advmod aux nsubj root det compound cc conj obj mark advcl obj case nmod nmod punct

text: How do I prevent negative bias from hindering learning ?
label: advmod aux nsubj root amod obj mark advcl obj punct

text: In this section , you will continue to increase your ability as an informed learner .
label: case det obl punct nsubj aux root mark xcomp nmod obj case det amod obl punct

text: Here you will explore how much of an influence motivation has on learning , as well as how to use motivation to purposefully take an active role in any learning activity .
label: advmod nsubj aux root advmod obj case det obl nsubj acl case obl punct cc fixed fixed conj mark acl obj mark advmod advcl det amod obj case det compound nmod punct

text: Rather than passively attempting to absorb new information , you will learn how to make conscious decisions about the methods of learning you will use ( based on what you intend to do with the information ) , how you will select and use learning materials that are appropriate for your needs , and how persistent you will be in the learning activity .
label: mark fixed advmod advcl mark xcomp amod obj punct nsubj aux root obj mark acl amod obj case det nmod case nmod nsubj aux acl punct advcl case obl nsubj acl mark xcomp case det obl punct punct conj nsubj aux advcl cc conj compound obj nsubj cop acl case nmod obl punct cc advmod conj nsubj aux advcl case det compound obl punct

text: There are three main motivation concepts that have been found to directly relate to learning .
label: expl root nummod amod compound nsubj nsubj aux aux acl mark advmod xcomp case obl punct

text: Each of these has been proven to mean the difference between success and failure .
label: nsubj case nmod aux aux root mark xcomp det obj case nmod cc conj punct

text: You will find that each of these is a strong tool that will enable you to engage with learning material in a way that not only suits your needs , but also gives you ownership over your own learning processes .
label: nsubj aux root mark nsubj case nmod cop det amod ccomp nsubj aux acl obj mark xcomp case compound obl case det obl nsubj advmod advmod acl nmod obj punct cc advmod conj iobj obj case nmod amod compound nmod punct

text: Resilience and Grit
label: root cc conj

text: While much of this chapter will cover very specific aspects about the act of learning , in this section , we will present different information that may at first seem unrelated .
label: mark nsubj case det nmod aux advcl advmod amod obj case det nmod case nmod punct case det obl punct nsubj aux root amod obj nsubj aux case obl acl xcomp punct

text: Some people would consider it more of a personal outlook than a learning practice , and yet it has a significant influence on the ability to learn .
label: det nsubj aux root obj xcomp case det amod obl case det compound obl punct cc advmod nsubj conj det amod obj case det nmod mark acl punct

text: What we are talking about here is called grit or resilience .
label: nsubj nsubj aux acl obl advmod aux root xcomp cc conj punct

text: Grit can be defined as personal perseverance toward a task or goal .
label: nsubj aux aux root case amod obl case det nmod cc conj punct

text: In learning , it can be thought of as a trait that drives a person to keep trying until they succeed .
label: case obl punct nsubj aux aux root case case det obl nsubj acl det obj mark xcomp xcomp mark nsubj advcl punct

text: It is not tied to talent or ability , but is simply a tendency to not give up until something is finished or accomplished .
label: nsubj aux advmod root case obl cc conj punct cc cop advmod det conj mark advmod acl compound mark nsubj aux advcl cc conj punct

text: Figure 2.3
label: root dep

text: U.S. Army veteran and captain of the U.S. Invictus team , Will Reynolds , races to the finish line .
label: compound compound nsubj cc conj case det compound compound nmod punct appos flat punct root case det compound obl punct

text: ( Credit : DoD News / Flickr / Attribution 2.0 Generic ( CC-BY 2.0 ) )
label: punct root punct compound dep punct list punct list dep amod punct appos dep punct punct

text: The study showed that grit and perseverance were better predictors of academic success and achievement than talent or IQ .
label: det nsubj root mark nsubj cc conj cop amod ccomp case amod nmod cc conj case obl cc conj punct

text: This personality trait was defined as “ grit ” by the psychologist Angela Duckworth . 1
label: det compound nsubj aux root case punct obl punct case det obl appos flat punct dep

text: In a 2007 study Duckworth and colleagues found that individuals with high grit were able to maintain motivation in learning tasks despite failures .
label: case det compound obl nsubj cc conj root mark nsubj case amod nmod cop ccomp mark xcomp obj case compound nmod case obl punct

text: The study examined a cross section of learning environments , such as GPA scores in Ivy League universities , dropout rates at West Point , rankings in the National Spelling Bee , and general educational attainment for adults .
label: det nsubj root det compound obj case compound nmod punct case fixed compound nmod case compound compound nmod punct compound conj case compound nmod punct conj case det amod compound nmod punct cc amod amod conj case nmod punct

text: What the results showed was that grit and perseverance were better predictors of academic success and achievement than talent or IQ .
label: nsubj det nsubj acl cop mark nsubj cc conj cop amod root case amod nmod cc conj case obl cc conj punct

text: Duckworth , A. L. ; Peterson , C. ; Matthews , M. D. ; Kelly , D. R. ( June 2007 ) . " Grit : Perseverance and passion for long - term goals " .
label: root punct flat flat punct conj punct flat punct conj punct flat flat punct conj punct flat flat punct nmod nmod punct punct punct list punct appos cc conj case amod punct compound nmod punct punct

text: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology . 92 ( 6 ) : 1087 – 1101 . doi:10.1037/0022-3514.92.6.1087 . PMID 17547490 .
label: root case compound cc conj nmod punct dep punct dep punct punct appos case nmod punct list punct list dep punct

text: Applying Grit
label: root obj

text: The concept of grit is an easy one to dismiss as something taken for granted .
label: det nsubj case nmod cop det amod root mark acl case obl acl case obl punct

text: In our culture , we have a number of sayings and aphorisms that capture the essence of grit : “ If at first you do not succeed , try , try again , ” or the famous quote by Thomas Edison : “ Genius is one percent inspiration , ninety - nine percent perspiration . ”
label: case nmod obl punct nsubj root det obj case nmod cc conj nsubj acl det obj case nmod punct punct mark case obl nsubj aux advmod advcl punct parataxis punct parataxis advmod punct punct cc det amod conj case nmod flat punct punct nsubj cop nummod nmod appos punct compound punct nummod nmod conj punct punct

text: The problem is we all understand the concept , but actually applying it takes work .
label: det nsubj cop nsubj det root det obj punct cc advmod csubj obj conj obj punct

text: If the task we are trying to complete is a difficult one , it can take a lot of work .
label: mark det nsubj nsubj aux acl mark xcomp cop det amod advcl punct nsubj aux root det obj case nmod punct

text: The first step in applying grit is to adopt an attitude that looks directly to the end goal as the only acceptable outcome .
label: det amod nsubj mark acl obj cop mark root det obj nsubj acl advmod case det compound obl case det amod amod obl punct

text: With this attitude comes an acceptance that you may not succeed on the first attempt — or the nineteenth attempt .
label: case det obl root det obj mark nsubj aux advmod acl case det amod obl punct cc det amod conj punct

text: Failed attempts are viewed as merely part of the process and seen as a very useful way to gain knowledge that moves you toward success .
label: amod nsubj aux root case advmod obl case det nmod cc conj case det advmod amod obl mark acl obj nsubj acl obj case obl punct

text: An example of this would be studying for an exam .
label: det nsubj case nmod aux cop root case det obl punct

text: In your first attempt at studying you simply reread the chapters of your textbook covered in the exam .
label: case nmod amod obl mark acl nsubj advmod root det obj case nmod nmod acl case det obl punct

text: You find that while this reinforces some of the knowledge you have gained , it does not ensure you have all the information you will need to do well on the test .
label: nsubj root mark mark nsubj advcl obj case det nmod nsubj aux acl punct nsubj aux advmod ccomp nsubj ccomp det det obj nsubj aux acl mark advcl advmod case det obl punct

text: You know that if you simply read the chapters yet again , there is no guarantee you are going to be any more successful .
label: nsubj root mark mark nsubj advmod advcl det obj advmod advmod punct expl ccomp det nsubj nsubj aux acl mark cop advmod advmod xcomp punct

text: You determine that you need to find a different approach .
label: nsubj root mark nsubj ccomp mark xcomp det amod obj punct

text: In other words , your first attempt was not a complete failure , but it did not achieve the end goal , so you try again with a different method .
label: case amod obl punct nmod amod nsubj cop advmod det amod root punct cc nsubj aux advmod conj det compound obj punct advmod nsubj parataxis advmod case det amod obl punct

text: On your second try , you copy down all of the main points onto a piece of paper using the section headlines from the chapters .
label: case nmod amod obl punct nsubj root compound obj case det amod nmod case det obl case nmod advcl det compound obj case det nmod punct

text: After a short break you come back to your list and write down a summary of what you know about each item on your list .
label: case det amod obl nsubj root advmod case nmod obl cc conj compound det obj case nmod nsubj acl case det obl case nmod nmod punct

text: This accomplishes two things : first , you are able to immediately spot areas where you need to learn more , and second , you can check your summaries against the text to make certain what you know is correct and adequate .
label: nsubj root nummod obj punct advmod punct nsubj cop parataxis mark advmod xcomp obj advmod nsubj acl mark xcomp obj punct cc advmod punct nsubj aux conj nmod obj case det obl mark advcl xcomp nsubj nsubj acl cop ccomp cc conj punct

text: In this example , while you may not have yet achieved complete success , you will have learned what you need to do next .
label: case det obl punct mark nsubj aux advmod aux advmod advcl amod obj punct nsubj aux aux root obj nsubj acl mark xcomp advmod punct

text: In true grit fashion , for your next try , you study those items on your list where you found you needed a bit more information , and then you go through your list again .
label: case amod compound obl punct case nmod amod obl punct nsubj root det obj case nmod nmod advmod nsubj acl nsubj ccomp det obl amod obj punct cc advmod nsubj conj case nmod obl advmod punct

text: This time you are able to write down summaries of all the important points , and you are confident you have the knowledge you need to do well on the exam .
label: det obl nsubj cop root mark xcomp compound obj case det det amod nmod punct cc nsubj cop conj nsubj ccomp det obj nsubj acl mark advcl advmod case det obl punct

text: After this , you still do not stop , but instead you change your approach to use other methods that keep what you have learned fresh in your mind .
label: case obl punct nsubj advmod aux advmod root punct cc advmod nsubj conj nmod obj mark advcl amod obj nsubj acl obj nsubj aux acl xcomp case nmod obl punct

text: 1 The Americas , Europe , and Africa Before 1492
label: dep det root punct conj punct cc conj case nmod

text: 1.1 The Americas
label: dep det root

text: Learning Objectives
label: compound root

text: By the end of this section , you will be able to :
label: case det obl case det nmod punct nsubj aux cop root xcomp punct

text: Locate on a map the major American civilizations before the arrival of the Spanish
label: root case det obl det amod amod obj case det nmod case det nmod

text: Discuss the cultural achievements of these civilizations
label: root det amod obj case det nmod

text: Discuss the differences and similarities between lifestyles , religious practices , and customs among the native peoples
label: root det obj cc conj case nmod punct amod conj punct cc conj case det amod nmod

text: Figure 1.2
label: root dep

text: ( credit : modification of work by Architect of the Capitol )
label: punct root punct dep case nmod case nmod case det nmod punct

text: Some scholars believe that between nine and fifteen thousand years ago , a land bridge existed between Asia and North America that we now call Beringia .
label: det nsubj root mark case compound cc conj nummod obl advmod punct det compound nsubj ccomp case obl cc compound conj obj nsubj advmod acl xcomp punct

text: The first inhabitants of what would be named the Americas migrated across this bridge in search of food .
label: det amod nsubj case nmod aux aux acl det xcomp root case det obl case obl case nmod punct

text: When the glaciers melted , water engulfed Beringia , and the Bering Strait was formed .
label: advmod det nsubj advcl punct nsubj root obj punct cc det compound nsubj aux conj punct

text: Later settlers came by boat across the narrow strait .
label: advmod nsubj root case obl case det amod obl punct

text: ( The fact that Asians and American Indians share genetic markers on a Y chromosome lends credibility to this migration theory . )
label: punct det nsubj mark nsubj cc amod conj acl amod obj case det compound nmod root obj case det compound obl punct punct

text: Continually moving southward , the settlers eventually populated both North and South America , creating unique cultures that ranged from the highly complex and urban Aztec civilization in what is now Mexico City to the woodland tribes of eastern North America .
label: advmod advcl advmod punct det nsubj advmod root cc compound cc conj obj punct advcl amod obj nsubj acl case det advmod amod cc conj compound obl case nmod cop advmod acl flat case det compound obl case amod compound nmod punct

text: Recent research along the west coast of South America suggests that migrant populations may have traveled down this coast by water as well as by land .
label: amod nsubj case det compound nmod case compound nmod root mark amod nsubj aux aux ccomp case det obl case obl cc fixed fixed case conj punct

text: Researchers believe that about ten thousand years ago , humans also began the domestication of plants and animals , adding agriculture as a means of sustenance to hunting and gathering techniques .
label: nsubj root mark advmod compound nummod obl advmod punct nsubj advmod ccomp det obj case nmod cc conj punct advcl obj case det obl case nmod case compound cc conj obl punct

text: With this agricultural revolution , and the more abundant and reliable food supplies it brought , populations grew and people were able to develop a more settled way of life , building permanent settlements .
label: case det amod obl punct cc det advmod amod cc conj compound conj nsubj acl punct nsubj root cc nsubj cop conj mark xcomp det advmod amod obj case nmod punct advcl amod obj punct

text: Nowhere in the Americas was this more obvious than in Mesoamerica ( Figure 1.3 ) .
label: advmod case det obl cop nsubj advmod root mark case obl punct dep dep punct punct

text: Figure 1.3
label: root dep

text: This map shows the extent of the major civilizations of the Western Hemisphere .
label: det nsubj root det obj case det amod nmod case det amod nmod punct

text: In South America , early civilizations developed along the coast because the high Andes and the inhospitable Amazon Basin made the interior of the continent less favorable for settlement .
label: case compound obl punct amod nsubj root case det obl mark det amod nsubj cc det amod compound conj advcl det obj case det nmod advmod xcomp case obl punct

text: THE FIRST AMERICANS : THE OLMEC
label: det amod root punct det appos

text: Mesoamerica is the geographic area stretching from north of Panama up to the desert of central Mexico .
label: nsubj cop det amod root acl case obl case nmod case fixed det obl case amod nmod punct

text: Although marked by great topographic , linguistic , and cultural diversity , this region cradled a number of civilizations with similar characteristics .
label: mark advcl case amod amod punct amod punct cc conj obl punct det nsubj root det obj case nmod case amod nmod punct

text: Mesoamericans were polytheistic ; their gods possessed both male and female traits and demanded blood sacrifices of enemies taken in battle or ritual bloodletting .
label: nsubj cop root punct nmod nsubj parataxis cc amod cc conj obj cc conj compound obj case nmod acl case obl cc compound conj punct

text: Corn , or maize , domesticated by 5000 BCE , formed the basis of their diet .
label: nsubj punct cc conj punct acl case obl advmod punct root det obj case nmod nmod punct

text: They developed a mathematical system , built huge edifices , and devised a calendar that accurately predicted eclipses and solstices and that priest - astronomers used to direct the planting and harvesting of crops .
label: nsubj root det amod obj punct conj amod obj punct cc conj det obj nsubj advmod acl obj cc conj cc obj compound punct nsubj conj mark advcl det obj cc conj case nmod punct

text: Most important for our knowledge of these peoples , they created the only known written language in the Western Hemisphere ; researchers have made much progress in interpreting the inscriptions on their temples and pyramids .
label: advmod advcl case nmod obl case det nmod punct nsubj root det amod amod amod obj case det amod nmod punct nsubj aux parataxis amod obj mark acl det obj case nmod nmod cc conj punct

text: Though the area had no overarching political structure , trade over long distances helped diffuse culture .
label: mark det nsubj advcl det amod amod obj punct nsubj case amod nmod root xcomp obj punct

text: Weapons made of obsidian , jewelry crafted from jade , feathers woven into clothing and ornaments , and cacao beans that were whipped into a chocolate drink formed the basis of commerce .
label: nsubj acl case obl punct conj acl case obl punct conj acl case obl cc conj punct cc compound conj nsubj aux acl case det compound obl root det obj case nmod punct

text: The mother of Mesoamerican cultures was the Olmec civilization .
label: det nsubj case amod nmod cop det amod root punct

text: Flourishing along the hot Gulf Coast of Mexico from about 1200 to about 400 BCE , the Olmec produced a number of major works of art , architecture , pottery , and sculpture .
label: advcl case det amod compound obl case nmod case advmod obl case advmod obl advmod punct det nsubj root det obj case amod nmod case nmod punct conj punct conj punct cc conj punct

text: Most recognizable are their giant head sculptures ( Figure 1.4 ) and the pyramid in La Venta .
label: advmod root cop nmod amod compound nsubj punct parataxis dep punct cc det conj case nmod flat punct

text: The Olmec built aqueducts to transport water into their cities and irrigate their fields .
label: det nsubj root obj mark advcl obj case nmod obl cc conj nmod obj punct

text: They grew maize , squash , beans , and tomatoes .
label: nsubj root obj punct conj punct conj punct cc conj punct

text: They also bred small domesticated dogs which , along with fish , provided their protein .
label: nsubj advmod root amod amod obj nsubj punct advmod case obl punct acl nmod obj punct

text: Although no one knows what happened to the Olmec after about 400 BCE , in part because the jungle reclaimed many of their cities , their culture was the base upon which the Maya and the Aztec built .
label: mark det nsubj advcl obj acl case det obl case advmod obl advmod punct case obl mark det nsubj advcl obj case nmod obl punct nmod nsubj cop det root case obl det nsubj cc det conj acl punct

text: It was the Olmec who worshipped a rain god , a maize god , and the feathered serpent so important in the future pantheons of the Aztecs ( who called him Quetzalcoatl ) and the Maya ( to whom he was Kukulkan ) .
label: expl cop det root nsubj acl det compound obj punct det compound conj punct cc det amod conj advmod amod case det amod obl case det nmod punct nsubj acl obj xcomp punct cc det conj punct case obl nsubj cop acl punct punct

text: The Olmec also developed a system of trade throughout Mesoamerica , giving rise to an elite class .
label: det nsubj advmod root det obj case nmod case obl punct advcl obj case det amod obl punct

text: Figure 1.4
label: root dep

text: The Olmec carved heads from giant boulders that ranged from four to eleven feet in height and could weigh up to fifty tons .
label: det nsubj root obj case amod obl nsubj acl case obl case nummod obl case nmod cc aux conj advmod fixed nummod obl punct

text: All these figures have flat noses , slightly crossed eyes , and large lips .
label: det det nsubj root amod obj punct advmod amod conj punct cc amod conj punct

text: These physical features can be seen today in some of the peoples indigenous to the area .
label: det amod nsubj aux aux root obl case obl case det nmod amod case det obl punct

text: THE MAYA
label: det root

text: After the decline of the Olmec , a city rose in the fertile central highlands of Mesoamerica .
label: case det obl case det nmod punct det nsubj root case det amod amod obl case nmod punct

text: One of the largest population centers in pre-Columbian America and home to more than 100,000 people at its height in about 500 CE , Teotihuacan was located about thirty miles northeast of modern Mexico City .
label: advcl case det amod compound nmod case amod nmod cc conj case advmod fixed nummod nmod case nmod obl case advmod obl advmod punct nsubj aux root advmod nummod obl obl case amod obl flat punct

text: The ethnicity of this settlement ’s inhabitants is debated ; some scholars believe it was a multiethnic city .
label: det nsubj case det nmod case nmod aux root punct det nsubj parataxis nsubj cop det amod ccomp punct

text: Large - scale agriculture and the resultant abundance of food allowed time for people to develop special trades and skills other than farming .
label: amod punct compound nsubj cc det amod conj case nmod root obj mark nsubj mark acl amod obj cc conj amod case obl punct

text: Builders constructed over twenty - two hundred apartment compounds for multiple families , as well as more than a hundred temples .
label: nsubj root advmod compound punct compound nummod compound obj case amod nmod punct cc fixed fixed advmod fixed det nummod conj punct

text: Among these were the Pyramid of the Sun ( which is two hundred feet high ) and the Pyramid of the Moon ( one hundred and fifty feet high ) .
label: case root cop det nsubj case det nmod punct nsubj cop compound nummod obl acl punct cc det conj case det nmod punct compound nummod cc conj obl parataxis punct punct

text: Near the Temple of the Feathered Serpent , graves have been uncovered that suggest humans were sacrificed for religious purposes .
label: case det obl case det compound nmod punct nsubj aux aux root nsubj acl nsubj aux ccomp case amod obl punct

text: The city was also the center for trade , which extended to settlements on Mesoamerica ’s Gulf Coast .
label: det nsubj cop advmod det root case obl punct nsubj acl case obl case nmod case compound nmod punct

text: The Maya were one Mesoamerican culture that had strong ties to Teotihuacan .
label: det nsubj cop nummod amod root nsubj acl amod obj case nmod punct

text: The Maya ’s architectural and mathematical contributions were significant .
label: det nmod case amod cc conj nsubj cop root punct

text: Flourishing from roughly 2000 BCE to 900 CE in what is now Mexico , Belize , Honduras , and Guatemala , the Maya perfected the calendar and written language the Olmec had begun .
label: advcl case advmod obl advmod case obl advmod case obl cop advmod acl punct conj punct conj punct cc conj punct det nsubj root det obj cc amod conj det nsubj aux acl punct

text: They devised a written mathematical system to record crop yields and the size of the population , and to assist in trade .
label: nsubj root det amod amod obj mark advcl compound obj cc det conj case det nmod punct cc mark conj case obl punct

text: Surrounded by farms relying on primitive agriculture , they built the city - states of Copan , Tikal , and Chichen Itza along their major trade routes , as well as temples , statues of gods , pyramids , and astronomical observatories ( Figure 1.5 ) .
label: advcl case obl acl case amod obl punct nsubj root det compound punct obj case nmod punct conj punct cc conj flat case nmod amod compound obl punct cc fixed fixed conj punct conj case nmod punct conj punct cc amod conj punct dep dep punct punct

text: However , because of poor soil and a drought that lasted nearly two centuries , their civilization declined by about 900 CE and they abandoned their large population centers .
label: advmod punct case fixed amod obl cc det conj nsubj acl advmod nummod obl punct nmod nsubj root case advmod obl advmod cc nsubj conj nmod amod compound obj punct

text: Figure 1.5
label: root dep

text: El Castillo , located at Chichen Itza in the eastern Yucatán peninsula , served as a temple for the god Kukulkan .
label: nsubj flat punct acl case obl flat case det amod compound obl punct root case det obl case det nmod appos punct

text: Each side contains ninety - one steps to the top .
label: det nsubj root nummod punct compound obj case det nmod punct

text: When counting the top platform , the total number of stairs is three hundred and sixty - five , the number of days in a year .
label: advmod advcl det amod obj punct det amod nsubj case nmod cop nummod root cc compound punct conj punct det appos case nmod case det nmod punct

text: ( credit : Ken Thomas )
label: punct root punct dep flat punct

text: The Spanish found little organized resistance among the weakened Maya upon their arrival in the 1520s .
label: det nsubj root amod amod obj case det amod nmod case nmod obl case det nmod punct

text: However , they did find Mayan history , in the form of glyphs , or pictures representing words , recorded in folding books called codices ( the singular is codex ) .
label: advmod punct nsubj aux root amod obj punct case det nmod case nmod punct cc conj acl obj punct acl case amod obl acl xcomp punct det nsubj cop parataxis punct punct

text: In 1562 , Bishop Diego de Landa , who feared the converted natives had reverted to their traditional religious practices , collected and burned every codex he could find .
label: case obl punct nsubj flat flat flat punct nsubj acl det amod nsubj aux ccomp case nmod amod amod obl punct root cc conj det obj nsubj aux acl punct

text: Today only a few survive .
label: obl advmod det nsubj root punct

text: Ethnocentrism and Cultural Relativism
label: root cc amod conj

text: Despite how much humans have in common , cultural differences are far more prevalent than cultural universals .
label: case advmod obl nsubj acl case obl punct amod nsubj cop advmod advmod root case amod obl punct

text: For example , while all cultures have language , analysis of particular language structures and conversational etiquette reveal tremendous differences .
label: case obl punct mark det nsubj advcl obj punct nsubj case amod compound nmod cc amod conj root amod obj punct

text: In some Middle Eastern cultures , it is common to stand close to others in conversation .
label: case det amod amod obl punct expl cop root mark csubj advmod case obl case obl punct

text: North Americans keep more distance and maintain a large “ personal space . ”
label: compound nsubj root amod obj cc conj det amod punct amod obj punct punct

text: Even something as simple as eating and drinking varies greatly from culture to culture .
label: advmod nsubj advmod amod mark advcl cc conj root advmod case obl case obl punct

text: If your professor comes into an early morning class holding a mug of liquid , what do you assume she is drinking ?
label: mark nmod nsubj advcl case det amod compound obl advcl det obj case nmod punct obj aux nsubj root nsubj aux ccomp punct

text: In the United States , it ’s most likely filled with coffee , not Earl Grey tea , a favorite in England , or Yak Butter tea , a staple in Tibet .
label: case det amod obl punct nsubj aux advmod advmod root case obl punct advmod compound flat conj punct det appos case nmod punct cc compound compound conj punct det appos case nmod punct

text: The way cuisines vary across cultures fascinates many people .
label: det nsubj nsubj acl case obl root amod obj punct

text: Some travelers pride themselves on their willingness to try unfamiliar foods , like celebrated food writer Anthony Bourdain , while others return home expressing gratitude for their native culture ’s fare .
label: det nsubj root obj case nmod obl mark acl amod obj punct case amod compound compound obl flat punct mark nsubj advcl advmod advcl obj case nmod amod nmod case nmod punct

text: Often , people in the United States express disgust at other cultures ’ cuisine and think that it ’s gross to eat meat from a dog or guinea pig , for example , while they do n’t question their own habit of eating cows or pigs .
label: advmod punct nsubj case det amod nmod root obj case amod nmod case nmod cc conj mark expl cop ccomp mark csubj obj case det nmod cc compound conj punct case obl punct mark nsubj aux advmod advcl nmod amod obj mark acl obj cc conj punct

text: Such attitudes are an example of ethnocentrism , or evaluating and judging another culture based on how it compares to one ’s own cultural norms .
label: amod nsubj cop det root case nmod punct cc conj cc conj det obj advcl mark obl nsubj advcl case nmod case amod amod obl punct

text: Ethnocentrism , as sociologist William Graham Sumner ( 1906 ) described the term , involves a belief or attitude that one ’s own culture is better than all others .
label: nsubj punct mark compound nsubj flat flat punct nmod punct advcl det obj punct root det obj cc conj mark nmod case amod nsubj cop acl case det obl punct

text: Almost everyone is a little bit ethnocentric .
label: advmod nsubj cop det amod obl root punct

text: For example , Americans tend to say that people from England drive on the “ wrong ” side of the road , rather than on the “ other ” side .
label: case obl punct nsubj root mark xcomp mark nsubj case nmod ccomp case det punct amod punct obl case det nmod punct cc fixed case det punct amod punct conj punct

text: Someone from a country where dog meat is standard fare might find it off - putting to see a dog in a French restaurant — not on the menu , but as a pet and patron ’s companion .
label: nsubj case det nmod advmod compound nsubj cop amod acl aux root expl advmod punct xcomp mark xcomp det obj case det amod obl punct advmod case det obl punct cc case det conj cc nmod case conj punct

text: A good example of ethnocentrism is referring to parts of Asia as the " Far East . "
label: det amod nsubj case nmod cop root case obl case nmod case det punct amod obl punct punct

text: One might question , " Far east of where ? "
label: nsubj aux root punct punct advmod ccomp case obl punct punct

text: A high level of appreciation for one ’s own culture can be healthy ; a shared sense of community pride , for example , connects people in a society .
label: det amod nsubj case nmod case nmod case amod nmod aux cop root punct det amod nsubj case compound nmod punct case obl punct parataxis obj case det obl punct

text: But ethnocentrism can lead to disdain or dislike for other cultures and could cause misunderstanding and conflict .
label: cc nsubj aux root case obl cc conj case amod nmod cc aux conj obj cc conj punct

text: People with the best intentions sometimes travel to a society to “ help ” its people , because they see them as uneducated or backward - essentially inferior .
label: nsubj case det amod nmod advmod root case det obl mark punct advcl punct nmod obj punct mark nsubj advcl obj case obl cc conj punct advmod appos punct

text: In reality , these travelers are guilty of cultural imperialism , the deliberate imposition of one ’s own cultural values on another culture .
label: case obl punct det nsubj cop root case amod obl punct det amod appos case nmod case amod amod nmod case det nmod punct

text: Europe ’s colonial expansion , begun in the sixteenth century , was often accompanied by a severe cultural imperialism .
label: nmod case amod nsubj punct acl case det amod obl punct aux advmod root case det amod amod obl punct

text: European colonizers often viewed the people in the lands they colonized as uncultured savages who were in need of European governance , dress , religion , and other cultural practices .
label: amod nsubj advmod root det obj case det nmod nsubj acl case amod obl nsubj cop case acl case amod nmod punct conj punct conj punct cc amod amod conj punct

text: A more modern example of cultural imperialism may include the work of international aid agencies who introduce agricultural methods and plant species from developed countries while overlooking indigenous varieties and agricultural approaches that are better suited to the particular region .
label: det advmod amod nsubj case amod nmod aux root det obj case amod compound nmod nsubj acl amod obj cc compound conj case amod nmod mark advcl amod obj cc amod conj nsubj cop advmod acl case det amod obl punct

text: Ethnocentrism can be so strong that when confronted with all of the differences of a new culture , one may experience disorientation and frustration .
label: nsubj aux cop advmod root mark advmod advcl case obl case det nmod case det amod nmod punct nsubj aux advcl obj cc conj punct

text: In sociology , we call this culture shock .
label: case obl punct nsubj root obj compound xcomp punct

text: A traveler from Chicago might find the nightly silence of rural Montana unsettling , not peaceful .
label: det nsubj case nmod aux root det amod obj case amod nmod xcomp punct advmod conj punct

text: An exchange student from China might be annoyed by the constant interruptions in class as other students ask questions — a practice that is considered rude in China .
label: det compound nsubj case nmod aux aux root case det amod obl case nmod mark amod nsubj acl obj punct det appos nsubj aux acl xcomp case obl punct

text: Perhaps the Chicago traveler was initially captivated with Montana ’s quiet beauty and the Chinese student was originally excited to see a U.S. - style classroom firsthand .
label: advmod det compound nsubj cop advmod root case nmod case amod obl cc det amod nsubj aux advmod conj mark xcomp det compound punct compound obj advmod punct

text: But as they experience unanticipated differences from their own culture , their excitement gives way to discomfort and doubts about how to behave appropriately in the new situation .
label: cc mark nsubj advcl amod obj case nmod amod nmod punct nmod nsubj root obl case obl cc conj case nmod mark acl advmod case det amod obl punct

text: Eventually , as people learn more about a culture , they recover from culture shock .
label: advmod punct mark nsubj advcl obj case det obl punct nsubj root case compound obl punct

text: Culture shock may appear because people are n’t always expecting cultural differences .
label: compound nsubj aux root mark nsubj aux advmod advmod advcl amod obj punct

text: Anthropologist Ken Barger ( 1971 ) discovered this when he conducted a participatory observation in an Inuit community in the Canadian Arctic .
label: nsubj flat flat punct nmod punct root obj advmod nsubj advcl det amod obj case det amod obl case det amod nmod punct

text: Originally from Indiana , Barger hesitated when invited to join a local snowshoe race .
label: advmod case obl punct nsubj root advmod advcl mark xcomp det amod compound obj punct

text: He knew he ’d never hold his own against these experts .
label: nsubj root nsubj aux advmod ccomp nmod obj case det obl punct

text: Sure enough , he finished last , to his mortification .
label: advmod advmod punct nsubj root advmod punct case nmod obl punct

text: But the tribal members congratulated him , saying , “ You really tried ! ”
label: cc det amod nsubj root obj punct advcl punct punct nsubj advmod ccomp punct punct

text: In Barger ’s own culture , he had learned to value victory .
label: case nmod case amod obl punct nsubj aux root mark xcomp obj punct

text: To the Inuit people , winning was enjoyable , but their culture valued survival skills essential to their environment : how hard someone tried could mean the difference between life and death .
label: case det amod obl punct csubj cop root punct cc nmod nsubj conj compound obj amod case nmod obl punct advmod csubj nsubj advcl aux parataxis det obj case nmod cc conj punct

text: Over the course of his stay , Barger participated in caribou hunts , learned how to take shelter in winter storms , and sometimes went days with little or no food to share among tribal members .
label: case det obl case nmod nmod punct nsubj root case compound obl punct conj obj mark acl obj case compound obl punct cc advmod conj obl case amod cc conj obl mark acl case amod obl punct

text: Trying hard and working together , two nonmaterial values , were indeed much more important than winning .
label: csubj advmod cc conj advmod punct nummod amod appos punct cop advmod advmod advmod root mark advcl punct

text: During his time with the Inuit tribe , Barger learned to engage in cultural relativism .
label: case nmod obl case det amod nmod punct nsubj root mark xcomp case amod obl punct

text: Cultural relativism is the practice of assessing a culture by its own standards rather than viewing it through the lens of one ’s own culture .
label: amod nsubj cop det root mark acl det obj case nmod amod obl cc fixed conj obj case det obl case nmod case amod nmod punct

text: Practicing cultural relativism requires an open mind and a willingness to consider , and even adapt to , new values and norms .
label: csubj amod obj root det amod obj cc det conj mark acl punct cc advmod conj obl punct amod obj cc conj punct

text: However , indiscriminately embracing everything about a new culture is not always possible .
label: advmod punct advmod csubj obj case det amod nmod cop advmod advmod root punct

text: Even the most culturally relativist people from egalitarian societies — ones in which women have political rights and control over their own bodies — would question whether the widespread practice of female genital mutilation in countries such as Ethiopia and Sudan should be accepted as a part of cultural tradition .
label: advmod det advmod advmod amod nsubj case amod nmod punct appos case obl nsubj acl amod obj cc conj case nmod amod nmod punct aux root mark det amod nsubj case amod compound nmod case nmod case fixed nmod cc conj aux aux ccomp case det obl case amod nmod punct

text: Sociologists attempting to engage in cultural relativism , then , may struggle to reconcile aspects of their own culture with aspects of a culture that they are studying .
label: nsubj acl mark xcomp case amod obl punct advmod punct aux root mark xcomp obj case nmod amod nmod case obl case det nmod obj nsubj aux acl punct

text: Sometimes when people attempt to rectify feelings of ethnocentrism and develop cultural relativism , they swing too far to the other end of the spectrum .
label: advmod advmod nsubj advcl mark xcomp obj case nmod cc conj amod obj punct nsubj root advmod advmod case det amod obl case det nmod punct

text: Xenocentrism is the opposite of ethnocentrism , and refers to the belief that another culture is superior to one ’s own .
label: nsubj cop det root case nmod punct cc conj case det obl mark det nsubj cop acl case nmod case obl punct

text: ( The Greek root word xeno , pronounced “ ZEE-no , ” means “ stranger ” or “ foreign guest . ” )
label: punct det amod compound nsubj appos punct acl punct xcomp punct punct root punct obj punct cc punct amod conj punct punct punct

text: An exchange student who goes home after a semester abroad or a sociologist who returns from the field may find it difficult to associate with the values of their own culture after having experienced what they deem a more upright or nobler way of living .
label: det compound nsubj nsubj acl advmod case det obl advmod cc det conj nsubj acl case det obl aux root expl xcomp mark xcomp case det obl case nmod amod nmod mark aux advcl obj nsubj acl det advmod amod cc conj xcomp mark acl punct

text: 24.2 Spacetime and Gravity
label: dep root cc conj

text: LEARNING OBJECTIVES
label: compound root

text: By the end of this section , you will be able to :
label: case det obl case det nmod punct nsubj aux cop root xcomp punct

text: Describe Einstein ’s view of gravity as the warping of spacetime in the presence of massive objects
label: root nmod case obj case nmod case det nmod case nmod case det nmod case amod nmod

text: Understand that Newton ’s concept of the gravitational force between two massive objects and Einstein ’s concept of warped spacetime are different explanations for the same observed accelerations of one massive object in the presence of another massive object
label: root mark nmod case nsubj case det amod nmod case nummod amod nmod cc nmod case conj case amod nmod cop amod ccomp case det amod amod nmod case nummod amod nmod case det nmod case det amod nmod

text: Is light actually bent from its straight - line path by the mass of Earth ?
label: aux nsubj advmod root case nmod amod punct compound obl case det obl case nmod punct

text: How can light , which has no mass , be affected by gravity ?
label: advmod aux nsubj punct nsubj acl det obj punct aux root case obl punct

text: Einstein preferred to think that it is space and time that are affected by the presence of a large mass ; light beams , and everything else that travels through space and time , then find their paths affected .
label: nsubj root mark xcomp mark expl cop ccomp cc conj nsubj aux advcl case det obl case det amod nmod punct compound nsubj punct cc conj advmod nsubj acl case obl cc conj punct advmod parataxis nmod obj xcomp punct

text: Light always follows the shortest path — but that path may not always be straight .
label: nsubj advmod root det amod obj punct cc det nsubj aux advmod advmod cop conj punct

text: This idea is true for human travel on the curved surface of planet Earth , as well .
label: det nsubj cop root case amod obl case det amod nmod case compound nmod punct advmod fixed punct

text: Say you want to fly from Chicago to Rome .
label: root nsubj ccomp mark xcomp case obl case obl punct

text: Since an airplane ca n’t go through the solid body of the Earth , the shortest distance is not a straight line but the arc of a great circle .
label: mark det nsubj aux advmod advcl case det amod obl case det nmod punct det amod nsubj cop advmod det amod root cc det conj case det amod nmod punct

text: Linkages : Mass , Space , and Time
label: root punct appos punct conj punct cc conj

text: To show what Einstein ’s insight really means , let ’s first consider how we locate an event in space and time .
label: mark advcl obj nmod case nsubj advmod acl punct root obj advmod xcomp obj nsubj advcl det obj case obl cc conj punct

text: For example , imagine you have to describe to worried school officials the fire that broke out in your room when your roommate tried cooking shish kebabs in the fireplace .
label: case obl punct root nsubj ccomp mark xcomp case amod compound obl det obj nsubj acl compound case nmod obl advmod nmod nsubj advcl xcomp compound obj case det obl punct

text: You explain that your dorm is at 6400 College Avenue , a street that runs in the left - right direction on a map of your town ; you are on the fifth floor , which tells where you are in the up - down direction ; and you are the sixth room back from the elevator , which tells where you are in the forward - backward direction .
label: nsubj root mark nmod nsubj cop case nummod compound ccomp punct det appos nsubj acl case det compound punct conj obl case det obl case nmod nmod punct nsubj cop case det amod conj punct nsubj acl obj nsubj advcl case det compound punct conj obl punct cc nsubj cop det amod conj advmod case det obl punct nsubj acl obj nsubj advcl case det compound punct conj obl punct

text: Then you explain that the fire broke out at 6:23 p.m. ( but was soon brought under control ) , which specifies the event in time .
label: advmod nsubj root mark det nsubj ccomp compound case obl nmod punct cc aux advmod conj case xcomp punct punct nsubj advcl det obj case obl punct

text: Any event in the universe , whether nearby or far away , can be pinpointed using the three dimensions of space and the one dimension of time .
label: det nsubj case det nmod punct mark acl cc advmod conj punct aux aux root advcl det nummod obj case nmod cc det nummod conj case nmod punct

text: Newton considered space and time to be completely independent , and that continued to be the accepted view until the beginning of the twentieth century .
label: nsubj root obj cc conj mark cop advmod xcomp punct cc nsubj conj mark cop det amod xcomp case det obl case det amod nmod punct

text: But Einstein showed that there is an intimate connection between space and time , and that only by considering the two together — in what we call spacetime — can we build up a correct picture of the physical world .
label: cc nsubj root mark expl ccomp det amod nsubj case nmod cc conj punct cc mark advmod mark advcl det obj advmod punct case obl nsubj acl xcomp punct aux nsubj conj compound det amod obj case det amod nmod punct

text: We examine spacetime a bit more closely in the next subsection .
label: nsubj root obj det obl advmod advmod case det amod obl punct

text: The gist of Einstein ’s general theory is that the presence of matter curves or warps the fabric of spacetime .
label: det nsubj case nmod case amod nmod cop mark det nsubj case nmod root cc conj det obj case nmod punct

text: This curving of spacetime is identified with gravity .
label: det nsubj case nmod aux root case obl punct

text: When something else — a beam of light , an electron , or the starship Enterprise — enters such a region of distorted spacetime , its path will be different from what it would have been in the absence of the matter .
label: advmod nsubj advmod punct det appos case nmod punct det conj punct cc det conj appos punct advcl det det obj case amod nmod punct nmod nsubj aux cop root case obl nsubj aux aux acl case det obl case det nmod punct

text: As American physicist John Wheeler summarized it : “ Matter tells spacetime how to curve ; spacetime tells matter how to move . ”
label: mark amod nsubj flat flat advcl obj punct punct nsubj root iobj obj mark acl punct nsubj parataxis iobj obj mark acl punct punct

text: The amount of distortion in spacetime depends on the mass of material that is involved and on how concentrated and compact it is .
label: det nsubj case nmod case nmod root case det obl case nmod nsubj aux acl cc mark advmod conj cc conj nsubj advcl punct

text: Terrestrial objects , such as the book you are reading , have far too little mass to introduce any significant distortion .
label: amod nsubj punct case fixed det nmod nsubj aux acl punct root advmod advmod amod obj mark advcl det amod obj punct

text: Newton ’s view of gravity is just fine for building bridges , skyscrapers , or amusement park rides .
label: nmod case nsubj case nmod cop advmod root mark advcl obj punct conj punct cc compound compound conj punct

text: General relativity does , however , have some practical applications .
label: amod nsubj aux punct advmod punct root det amod obj punct

text: The GPS ( Global Positioning System ) in every smartphone can tell you where you are within 5 to 10 meters only because the effects of general and special relativity on the GPS satellites in orbit around the Earth are taken into account .
label: det nsubj punct amod compound appos punct case det nmod aux root iobj obj nsubj advcl case nummod case nmod obl advmod mark det nsubj case amod cc conj nmod case det compound nmod case nmod case det nmod aux advcl case obl punct

text: Unlike a book or your roommate , stars produce measurable distortions in spacetime .
label: case det obl cc nmod conj punct nsubj root amod obj case nmod punct

text: A white dwarf , with its stronger surface gravity , produces more distortion just above its surface than does a red giant with the same mass .
label: det amod nsubj punct case nmod amod compound obl punct root amod obj advmod case nmod obl mark advcl det amod nsubj case det amod nmod punct

text: So , you see , we are eventually going to talk about collapsing stars again , but not before discussing Einstein ’s ideas ( and the evidence for them ) in more detail .
label: advmod punct nsubj parataxis punct nsubj aux advmod root mark xcomp case amod obl advmod punct cc advmod mark conj nmod case obj punct cc det conj case nmod punct case amod obl punct

text: Spacetime Examples
label: compound root

text: How can we understand the distortion of spacetime by the presence of some ( significant ) amount of mass ?
label: advmod aux nsubj root det obj case nmod case det nmod case det punct amod punct nmod case nmod punct

text: Let ’s try the following analogy .
label: root obj xcomp det amod obj punct

text: You may have seen maps of New York City that squeeze the full three dimensions of this towering metropolis onto a flat sheet of paper and still have enough information so tourists will not get lost .
label: nsubj aux aux root obj case amod compound nmod nsubj acl det amod nummod obj case det amod nmod case det amod obl case nmod cc advmod conj amod obj mark nsubj aux advmod aux advcl punct

text: Let ’s do something similar with diagrams of spacetime .
label: root obj xcomp obj amod case obl case nmod punct

text: Figure 24.7 , for example , shows the progress of a motorist driving east on a stretch of road in Kansas where the countryside is absolutely flat .
label: nsubj dep punct case obl punct root det obj case det nmod acl advmod case det obl case nmod case nmod advmod det nsubj cop advmod advcl punct

text: Since our motorist is traveling only in the east - west direction and the terrain is flat , we can ignore the other two dimensions of space .
label: mark nmod nsubj aux advcl advmod case det compound punct conj obl cc det nsubj cop conj punct nsubj aux root det amod nummod obj case nmod punct

text: The amount of time elapsed since he left home is shown on the y - axis , and the distance traveled eastward is shown on the x - axis .
label: det nsubj case nmod acl mark nsubj advcl obj aux root case det compound punct obl punct cc det nsubj acl advmod aux conj case det compound punct obl punct

text: From A to B he drove at a uniform speed ; unfortunately , it was too fast a uniform speed and a police car spotted him .
label: case obl case obl nsubj root case det amod obl punct advmod punct nsubj cop advmod amod det amod parataxis cc det compound nsubj conj obj punct

text: From B to C he stopped to receive his ticket and made no progress through space , only through time .
label: case obl case obl nsubj root mark advcl nmod obj cc conj det obj case nmod punct advmod case parataxis punct

text: From C to D he drove more slowly because the police car was behind him .
label: case obl case obl nsubj root advmod advmod mark det compound nsubj cop case advcl punct

text: Figure 24.7
label: root dep

text: Spacetime Diagram .
label: compound root punct

text: This diagram shows the progress of a motorist traveling east across the flat Kansas landscape .
label: det nsubj root det obj case det nmod acl advmod case det amod compound obl punct

text: Distance traveled is plotted along the horizontal axis .
label: nsubj acl aux root case det amod obl punct

text: The time elapsed since the motorist left the starting point is plotted along the vertical axis .
label: det nsubj acl mark det nsubj advcl det compound obj aux root case det amod obl punct

text: Now let ’s try illustrating the distortions of spacetime in two dimensions .
label: advmod root obj xcomp xcomp det obj case nmod case nummod obl punct

text: In this case , we will ( in our imaginations ) use a rubber sheet that can stretch or warp if we put objects on it .
label: case det obl punct nsubj aux punct case nmod obl punct root det compound obj nsubj aux acl cc conj mark nsubj advcl obj case obl punct

text: Let ’s imagine stretching our rubber sheet taut on four posts .
label: root obj xcomp xcomp nmod compound obj xcomp case nummod obl punct

text: To complete the analogy , we need something that normally travels in a straight line ( as light does ) .
label: mark advcl det obj punct nsubj root obj nsubj advmod acl case det amod obl punct mark nsubj advcl punct punct

text: Suppose we have an extremely intelligent ant — a friend of the comic book superhero Ant - Man , perhaps — that has been trained to walk in a straight line .
label: root nsubj ccomp det advmod amod obj punct det appos case det compound compound nmod compound punct appos punct advmod punct nsubj aux aux acl mark advcl case det amod obl punct

text: We begin with just the rubber sheet and the ant , simulating empty space with no mass in it .
label: nsubj root case advmod det compound obl cc det conj punct advcl amod obj mark det nsubj case acl punct

text: We put the ant on one side of the sheet and it walks in a beautiful straight line over to the other side ( Figure 24.8 ) .
label: nsubj root det obj case nummod obl case det nmod cc nsubj conj case det amod amod obl advmod case det amod obl punct dep dep punct punct

text: We next put a small grain of sand on the rubber sheet .
label: nsubj advmod root det amod obj case nmod case det compound obl punct

text: The sand does distort the sheet a tiny bit , but this is not a distortion that we or the ant can measure .
label: det nsubj aux root det obj det amod obl punct cc nsubj cop advmod det conj obj nsubj cc det conj aux acl punct

text: If we send the ant so it goes close to , but not on top of , the sand grain , it has little trouble continuing to walk in a straight line .
label: mark nsubj advcl det obj mark nsubj advcl xcomp case punct cc advmod case conj obl punct det compound obl punct nsubj root amod obj advcl mark xcomp case det amod obl punct

text: Now we grab something with a little more mass — say , a small pebble .
label: advmod nsubj root obj case det obl amod nmod punct discourse punct det amod appos punct

text: It bends or distorts the sheet just a bit around its position .
label: nsubj root cc conj det obj advmod det obl case nmod obl punct

text: If we send the ant into this region , it finds its path slightly altered by the distortion of the sheet .
label: mark nsubj advcl det obj case det obl punct nsubj root nmod obj advmod xcomp case det obl case det nmod punct

text: The distortion is not large , but if we follow the ant ’s path carefully , we notice it deviating slightly from a straight line .
label: det nsubj cop advmod root punct cc mark nsubj advcl det nmod case obj advmod punct nsubj conj obj xcomp advmod case det amod obl punct

text: The effect gets more noticeable as we increase the mass of the object that we put on the sheet .
label: det nsubj root advmod xcomp mark nsubj advcl det obj case det nmod obj nsubj acl case det obl punct

text: Let ’s say we now use a massive paperweight .
label: root obj xcomp nsubj advmod ccomp det amod obj punct

text: Such a heavy object distorts or warps the rubber sheet very effectively , putting a good sag in it .
label: det det amod nsubj root cc conj det compound obj advmod advmod punct advcl det amod obj case obl punct

text: From our point of view , we can see that the sheet near the paperweight is no longer straight .
label: case nmod obl case nmod punct nsubj aux root mark det nsubj case det nmod cop advmod advmod ccomp punct

text: 2.3 Measures of the Location of the Data
label: dep root case det nmod case det nmod

text: The common measures of location are quartiles and percentiles .
label: det amod nsubj case nmod cop root cc conj punct

text: Quartiles are special percentiles .
label: nsubj cop amod root punct

text: The first quartile , Q 1 , is the same as the 25th percentile , and the third quartile , Q 3 , is the same as the 75th percentile .
label: det amod nsubj punct appos dep punct cop det root case det amod obl punct cc det amod nsubj punct appos dep punct cop det conj case det amod obl punct

text: The median , M , is called both the second quartile and the 50th percentile .
label: det nsubj punct appos punct aux root cc det amod xcomp cc det amod conj punct

text: To calculate quartiles and percentiles , you must order the data from smallest to largest .
label: mark advcl obj cc conj punct nsubj aux root det obj case obl case obl punct

text: Quartiles divide ordered data into quarters .
label: nsubj root amod obj case obl punct

text: Percentiles divide ordered data into hundredths .
label: nsubj root amod obj case obl punct

text: Recall that a percent means one - hundredth .
label: root mark det nsubj ccomp nummod punct obj punct

text: So , percentiles mean the data is divided into 100 sections .
label: advmod punct nsubj root det nsubj aux ccomp case nummod obl punct

text: To score in the 90th percentile of an exam does not mean , necessarily , that you received 90 percent on a test .
label: mark csubj case det amod obl case det nmod aux advmod root punct advmod punct mark nsubj ccomp nummod obj case det nmod punct

text: It means that 90 percent of test scores are the same as or less than your score and that 10 percent of the test scores are the same as or greater than your test score .
label: nsubj root mark nummod nsubj case compound nmod cop det ccomp obl cc conj case nmod obl cc mark nummod nsubj case det compound nmod cop det conj obl cc conj case nmod compound obl punct

text: Percentiles are useful for comparing values .
label: nsubj cop root mark advcl obj punct

text: For this reason , universities and colleges use percentiles extensively .
label: case det obl punct nsubj cc conj root obj advmod punct

text: One instance in which colleges and universities use percentiles is when SAT results are used to determine a minimum testing score that will be used as an acceptance factor .
label: nummod nsubj case obl nsubj cc conj acl obj cop root compound nsubj aux advcl mark advcl det amod compound obj nsubj aux aux acl case det compound obl punct

text: For example , suppose Duke accepts SAT scores at or above the 75th percentile .
label: case obl punct root nsubj ccomp compound obj case cc conj det amod nmod punct

text: That translates into a score of at least 1220 .
label: nsubj root case det obl case case nmod nmod punct

text: Percentiles are mostly used with very large populations .
label: nsubj aux advmod root case advmod amod obl punct

text: Therefore , if you were to say that 90 percent of the test scores are less , and not the same or less , than your score , it would be acceptable because removing one particular data value is not significant .
label: advmod punct mark nsubj aux mark advcl mark nummod nsubj case det compound nmod cop ccomp punct cc advmod det conj cc conj punct case nmod obl punct nsubj aux cop root mark csubj nummod amod compound obj cop advmod advcl punct

text: The median is a number that measures the center of the data .
label: det nsubj cop det root nsubj acl det obj case det nmod punct

text: You can think of the median as the middle value , but it does not actually have to be one of the observed values .
label: nsubj aux root case det obl case det amod obl punct cc nsubj aux advmod advmod conj mark cop xcomp case det amod nmod punct

text: It is a number that separates ordered data into halves .
label: nsubj cop det root nsubj acl amod obj case obl punct

text: Half the values are the same number or smaller than the median , and half the values are the same number or larger .
label: det det nsubj cop det amod root cc conj case det obl punct cc det det nsubj cop det amod conj cc conj punct

text: For example , consider the following data :
label: case obl punct root det amod obj punct
root punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj

text: Ordered from smallest to largest :
label: root case obl case obl punct
root punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj

text: When a data set has an even number of data values , the median is equal to the average of the two middle values when the data are arranged in ascending order ( least to greatest ) .
label: advmod det compound nsubj advcl det amod obj case compound nmod punct det nsubj cop root case det obl case det nummod amod nmod advmod det nsubj aux acl case amod obl punct parataxis case obl punct punct

text: When a data set has an odd number of data values , the median is equal to the middle value when the data are arranged in ascending order .
label: advmod det compound nsubj advcl det amod obj case compound nmod punct det nsubj cop root case det amod obl advmod det nsubj aux acl case amod obl punct

text: Since there are 14 observations ( an even number of data values ) , the median is between the seventh value , 6.8 , and the eighth value , 7.2 .
label: mark expl advcl nummod nsubj punct det amod appos case compound nmod punct punct det nsubj cop case det amod root punct appos punct cc det amod conj punct appos punct

text: To find the median , add the two values together and divide by two .
label: mark advcl det obj punct root det nummod obj advmod cc conj case obl punct
punct nsubj cc conj punct acl obl root xcomp

text: The median is seven .
label: det nsubj cop root punct

text: Half of the values are smaller than seven and half of the values are larger than seven .
label: nsubj case det nmod cop root case obl cc nsubj case det nmod cop conj case obl punct

text: Quartiles are numbers that separate the data into quarters .
label: nsubj cop root nsubj acl det obj case obl punct

text: Quartiles may or may not be part of the data .
label: nsubj root cc aux advmod cop conj case det nmod punct

text: To find the quartiles , first find the median , or second , quartile .
label: mark advcl det obj punct advmod root det amod punct cc conj punct obj punct

text: The first quartile , Q 1 , is the middle value of the lower half of the data , and the third quartile , Q 3 , is the middle value , or median , of the upper half of the data .
label: det amod nsubj punct appos dep punct cop det amod root case det amod nmod case det nmod punct cc det amod nsubj punct appos dep punct cop det amod conj punct cc conj punct case det amod nmod case det nmod punct

text: To get the idea , consider the same data set :
label: mark advcl det obj punct root det amod compound obj punct
root punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj punct conj

text: The data set has an even number of values ( 14 data values ) , so the median will be the average of the two middle values ( the average of 6.8 and 7.2 ) , which is calculated as ( 6.8 + 7.2 ) / 2 and equals 7 .
label: det compound nsubj root det amod obj case nmod punct nummod compound appos punct punct advmod det nsubj aux cop det parataxis case det nummod amod nmod punct det appos case nmod cc conj punct punct nsubj aux acl case punct obl cc conj punct acl obl cc conj obj punct

text: So , the median , or second quartile ( Q 2 ) , is 7 .
label: advmod punct det nsubj punct cc amod conj punct appos dep punct punct cop root punct

text: The first quartile is the median of the lower half of the data , so if we divide the data into seven values in the lower half and seven values in the upper half , we can see that we have an odd number of values in the lower half .
label: det amod nsubj cop det root case det amod nmod case det nmod punct advmod mark nsubj advcl det obj case nummod obl case det amod nmod cc nummod conj case det amod nmod punct nsubj aux parataxis mark nsubj ccomp det amod obj case nmod case det amod obl punct

text: Thus , the median of the lower half , or the first quartile ( Q 1 ) will be the middle value , or 2 .

text: Using the same procedure , we can see that the median of the upper half , or the third quartile ( Q 3 ) will be the middle value of the upper half , or 9 .
